subject: Tests in same package, again (was: Re: [junit] Newbie question about 	the best practice for organizing and running tests)

messageBody:
2009/3/26 Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...>:
> I still find that testing the internal workings of a class can help
> converge toward a bug faster, so putting the tests in the same package
> as the code under test or relaxing the visibility of certain methods
> (typically, to "package") helps testing at a lower level.

That's the convention at my new job, and I'm ambivalent about it.
Given a piece of code I didn't write, permission to edit the package,
and 30 minutes to write a test and fix, I'd probably prefer the "tests
in the same package" convention. And in situations where that's a
common edit case, it probably makes sense.

However, I miss the client-interface feedback that Nat mentioned.
Using a car metaphor, it's like my tests can tell me "hey, checking
the oil dipstick every couple days is annoying: why not build in a
'Oil Low' indicator light?" In code in which I intend to work
long-term, I'd prefer the different-package tests.

David Saff
